raw_text:
Apple unveils low-cost 'Mac mini'
 
 Apple has unveiled a new, low-cost Macintosh computer for the masses, billed as the Mac mini.
 
 Chief executive Steve Jobs showed off the new machine at his annual MacWorld speech, in San Francisco. The $499 Macintosh, sold for £339 in the UK, was described by Jobs as the "most important Mac" made by Apple. Mr Jobs also unveiled the iPod shuffle, a new music player using cheaper flash memory rather than hard drives, which are used in more expensive iPods.
 
 The new computer shifts the company into new territory - traditionally, the firm is known as a design and innovation-led firm rather than as a mass-market manufacturer. The Mac mini comes without a monitor, keyboard and mouse, and a second version with a larger hard drive will also be sold for $599.
 
 The machine - which will be available from 22 January - was described by Jobs as "BYODKM... bring your own display, keyboard, and mouse". In an attempt to win over Windows PC customers, Mr Jobs said it would appeal to people thinking of changing operating systems. "People who are thinking of switching will have no more excuses," he said. "It's the newest and most affordable Mac ever." The new computer has been the subject of speculation for several weeks and while few people will be surprised by the announcement many analysts had already said it was a sensible move. In January, Apple sued a website after it published what it said were specifications for the new computer. Ian Harris, deputy editor of UK magazine Mac Format, said the machine would appeal to PC-owning consumers who had purchased an iPod.
 
 "They want a further taste of Mac because they like what they have seen with iPod." Harris added: "Everybody thought that Apple was happy to remain a niche maker of luxury computers, and moving into a market dominated by low margin manufacturers like Dell is a bold move. "But it shows that Apple is keen to capitalise on the mass market success it's had with the iPod. The Mac mini will appeal to PC users looking for an attractive, 'no fuss' computer." The new iPod shuffle comes in two versions - one offering 512mb of storage for $99 (£69 in the Uk) and a second with one gigabyte of storage for $149 (£99) - and went on sale Tuesday. The music player has no display and will play songs either consecutively or shuffled. The smaller iPod will hold about 120 songs, said Mr Jobs. Mr Jobs told the delegates at MacWorld that iPod already had a 65% market share of all digital music players.
llama3.2:1b: Apple unveils new low-cost "Mac mini" computer for mass markets, priced at $499 in the US, with no monitor, keyboard and mouse, to appeal to Windows PC customers who are looking for an affordable alternative to their existing operating systems. The company also releases a cheaper version of its iPod shuffle music player, which will be available from January 22.
llama3.2:3b: Apple unveils low-cost Mac mini for $499 in the US and £339 in the UK, sold without monitor, keyboard, and mouse. The new machine has been described as "the most important Mac" made by Apple and will be available from January 22nd. A second version with a larger hard drive will also be sold for $599.
gemma2:2b: Apple unveiled a low-cost "Mac mini" computer for $499 (or £339 in the UK).  The machine is designed to appeal to both PC users and those looking to switch to Macs. It is sold without a monitor, keyboard, or mouse, and a larger model with more storage is also available. Apple also unveiled a new iPod shuffle, offering 512MB or 1GB of storage. The shuffle has no display and plays songs in either order or random order.  Apple's move into mass-market manufacturing was anticipated by analysts.
qwen2.5:0.5b: Apple unveils low-cost Mac mini featuring iPod shuffle
qwen2.5:1.5b: Apple unveils low-cost "Mac mini" at MacWorld: $499 model (UK £339) and larger hard drive version ($599), intended to attract Windows PC users considering switch from Apple's MacBook line, aimed to expand market appeal to non-Apple consumers.
qwen2.5:3b: Apple unveiled a new low-cost Mac mini at its annual MacWorld speech in San Francisco. Priced at $499 (UK £339), it's described as "the most important Mac" by CEO Steve Jobs, and comes without peripherals like monitor, keyboard, and mouse. Available for $599 with larger storage, the machine is designed for users who want to bring their own devices. Additionally, Apple introduced the iPod shuffle, a cheaper music player using flash memory instead of hard drives, which went on sale two days after the Mac mini launch.
opencoder:1.5b: The unveiling unveils a new Mac mini computer with competitive pricing and a range of features, including a sleek, affordable design, an integrated gaming console, an affordable iPod shuffle, and a larger hard drive capacity.
smollm:1.7b:
The summary is concise, preserving key ideas and details:

1. Apple has unveiled a new, low-cost Macintosh computer for the masses, billed as the "Mac mini".
2. The company has also announced a new iPod shuffle that will be available in two versions - one with a monitor, keyboard and mouse, and another with a larger hard drive.
3. The new computer shifts Apple's focus into new territory, traditionally known for its design and innovation-led approach to manufacturing.
4. The Mac mini is the latest model from Apple, priced at $499 in the UK.
5. The machine - which will be available from 22 January - was described by Steve Jobs as "BYODKM... bring your own display, keyboard, and mouse".
6. The new iPod shuffle has no display or keyboard, but can play songs either consecutively or shuffled.
7. The company is offering the Mac mini at a price of $599 in the UK, which is lower than the original price of $499.
8. The new iPod shuffle will appeal to PC users who have purchased an iPod, and will offer 512mb of storage for $99 (£69 in the UK) or one gigabyte of storage for $149 (£99).
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, so I need to summarize this text about Apple's new "Mac mini" computer. Let me read through it carefully and extract the key points.

First, I see that Apple has unveiled a low-cost Macintosh for the masses. The main product is the $499 Mac mini, which was described as the "most important Mac" by Steve Jobs. He also introduced the iPod shuffle, which uses cheaper flash memory instead of hard drives. 

The new computer doesn't have a display, keyboard, or mouse—people typically get that from BYOD, bringing their own devices. It's targeted at Windows PC customers who might switch operating systems, and it appeals to those looking for "no fuss" computing. 

There are two versions: one with 512mb storage for $99 and another with a gigabyte for $149. The smaller version holds about 120 songs. It's expected to be available starting on January 22nd.

The user also mentioned that while some people might think Apple is still niche, moving into mass market PCs like Dell is bold. The new computer comes after a speculation but was discussed in detail by Mac Format.

So putting it all together, the summary should highlight the low cost, no display parts, BYOD approach, target audience for Windows users and OS switching, two versions with different storage, and availability details.
</think>

The Apple "Mac mini" is introduced as a budget-friendly, mass-market computer, described by Steve Jobs as the company's most significant product. It features a 512MB storage version available at $99 and a 1GB version at $149, designed for users who might switch operating systems. The device shifts Apple into a new market segment, targeting Windows PC customers. The "Mac mini" is expected to be launched starting January 22nd.
tinyllama:1.1b: Apple has unveiled the low-cost "Mac mini," which is being billed as the company's most important product made for Apple users. The new device comes without a monitor, keyboard, and mouse, but features a second version with larger hard drive that will be available for $599 in January. The Mac mini is designed to appeal to consumers who have already purchased an iPod by offering the latest and most affordable Mac computer along with the new shuffle device. Apple's decision to make a budget-friendly option for the "Macintosh" platform shows that it is interested in capitalizing on the mass market success it has seen with the iPod, and will appeal to consumers who are looking for an attractive, yet no-fuss computer.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Apple has announced an affordable alternative to its popular Macintosh computers with the launch of the new low-cost 'Mac mini'. This innovative and versatile computer is designed specifically for everyday use, featuring a brand new design, lower price tag and more storage options than ever before. The new machine comes in two variants - one offering 512mb of storage for $99 (£69) and a second with 1 gigabyte of storage for $149 (£99). These models will be available from January 22, allowing potential buyers to take advantage of the new price point without compromising on performance or feature set. The Mac mini is expected to appeal to PC users who may have been thinking of changing operating systems, and features such as a built-in monitor, keyboard and mouse will appeal to those thinking of upgrading from their existing Windows setup. With a focus on innovation and affordability, Apple has once again demonstrated its ability to redefine the industry.
phi:2.7b: Apple unveils new low-cost Mac mini with flash memory for $499 and iPod shuffle with no display for £339 in the UK. The company shifts into mass-market territory by selling computers without monitors, keyboards or mice. CEO Steve Jobs also announced a second version with a larger hard drive for $599. The machine will appeal to PC users who like Apple's design. Apple sued a website after publishing specifications for the new computer. The new iPod shuffle has 512mb of storage and plays songs consecutively or shuffled. It comes in two versions, one with no display and costs £69.
orca-mini:3b: Apple unveils low-cost Mac mini at its annual MacWorld speech in San Francisco. The computer is available for $499 and comes with no monitor, keyboard, and mouse. It is designed to appeal to PC users who have purchased an iPod. Apple CEO Steve Jobs claims that the Mac mini is "the most important Mac" made by Apple. The company also unveils a new music player, the iPod shuffle, which comes in two versions: one with 512mb of storage for $99 and another with one gigabyte of storage for $149. The Mac mini will replace existing Mac computers and is available from 22 January.
hermes3:3b: Apple introduces low-cost 'Mac mini' computer. $499 device aims to attract Windows PC customers, shifting Apple towards mass-market manufacturer status.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: Apple introduced the low-cost Mac mini for $499 and £339 respectively, targeted at masses, in Steve Jobs' annual MacWorld speech. The computer comes without monitor, keyboard, and mouse, with an optional larger hard drive version available for $599. The Mac mini is seen as a bold move by Apple to expand its market share beyond its traditional design and innovation focus. It appeals to PC users looking for an attractive, "no fuss" computer and follows the success of the iPod. The new Mac mini will be available from 22 January.
chatgpt-4o-latest: Apple unveiled the Mac mini, a low-cost Macintosh computer priced at $499, aimed at attracting mass-market consumers and Windows PC users. CEO Steve Jobs introduced it at MacWorld, calling it Apple's "most important Mac." The Mac mini, available from January 22, comes without a monitor, keyboard, or mouse and has a $599 version with a larger hard drive. Jobs positioned it as an easy switch for Windows users. Analysts saw it as a strategic move to expand Apple's market beyond high-end computers, leveraging the iPod's success. Apple also introduced the iPod shuffle, a screenless music player using flash memory, available in 512MB ($99) and 1GB ($149) versions. Jobs highlighted Apple's 65% market share in digital music players.
stablelm2:1.6b: Apple announced their new low-cost "Mac mini" computer during Steve Jobs' annual MacWorld speech in San Francisco. The $1099 Macintosh will be sold for £1299 in the UK without a monitor, keyboard, and mouse. A second version with a larger hard drive will also be available starting January 2004. The Mac mini is Apple's new venture into mass market manufacturing as traditionally, they are known for design and innovation rather than mass production. It encourages people to "bring your own display, keyboard, and mouse." It will appeal to PC-owning consumers who have purchased an iPod, said Ian Harris of UK magazine Mac Format. The new iPod shuffle has two versions: one offering 2MB of storage for £199 (U.K.) and a second with one gigabyte of storage for £149. The music player has no display and will play songs either consecutively or shuffled, holding about 300 songs according "Jobs." iPod already has a 17% market share of all digital music players.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
Apple introduced a new, affordable Macintosh computer called the Mac mini, priced at $499 (£339 in the UK), during Steve Jobs' annual MacWorld speech in San Francisco. This machine, described as "the most important Mac ever made," features no monitor, keyboard, or mouse, prompting users to bring their own input devices—a strategy aimed at appealing to Windows PC customers and those considering switching to Apple's operating system. The Mac mini will be available from January 22nd.

Additionally, Jobs unveiled the iPod shuffle, priced at $99 (£69 in the UK) for 512mb storage and $149 (£99) for one gigabyte of storage. The device has no display and plays songs sequentially or shuffled. Apple's CEO stated that iPod already holds a 65% market share among digital music players.

This move into mass-market manufacturing marks a significant shift for the design-focused company, traditionally known for innovation rather than volume production. Analysts had anticipated such a strategy to capitalize on Apple's growing success with the iPod.
reference: Apple has unveiled a new, low-cost Macintosh computer for the masses, billed as the Mac mini.The $499 Macintosh, sold for £339 in the UK, was described by Jobs as the "most important Mac" made by Apple.The smaller iPod will hold about 120 songs, said Mr Jobs.Mr Jobs also unveiled the iPod shuffle, a new music player using cheaper flash memory rather than hard drives, which are used in more expensive iPods.In January, Apple sued a website after it published what it said were specifications for the new computer.Ian Harris, deputy editor of UK magazine Mac Format, said the machine would appeal to PC-owning consumers who had purchased an iPod.The new computer has been the subject of speculation for several weeks and while few people will be surprised by the announcement many analysts had already said it was a sensible move.Mr Jobs told the delegates at MacWorld that iPod already had a 65% market share of all digital music players.In an attempt to win over Windows PC customers, Mr Jobs said it would appeal to people thinking of changing operating systems.
